##########
File path: cpp/src/arrow/compute/kernels/scalar_validity.cc
##########
@@ -189,6 +191,72 @@ Status ConstBoolExec(KernelContext* ctx, const ExecBatch& batch, Datum* out) {
   return Status::OK();
 }
 
+struct NonZeroVisitor {
+   UInt32Builder *builder;

Review comment:
       AFAIK, indices in Arrow are usually represented with `int64_t`. Also, it might be the case that a different integer type is desired, so can these be generalized? Maybe using `NumericBuilder<...>` but these would not allow using `BooleanBuilder`.

issuetype.description: An improvement or enhancement to an existing feature or task.
issuetype.name: Improvement

fields.description:
This would be similar to Numpy's {{nonzero}} function:
[https://numpy.org/doc/stable/reference/generated/numpy.nonzero.html]

{code:python}
>>> arr = np.array([4,5,0,6,0,5])
>>> np.nonzero(arr)
(array([0, 1, 3, 5]),)
{code}
fields.summary: [C++] Create a compute function returning indices of non-zero values

comments.body: Suggestion taken from comments in ARROW-10423.

The mention of it in ARROW-10423 was I think in the context of a boolean array, for which the code already exists (indices of the set bits). 
I assume for other numeric types we would just do a `arr == 0` internally first?
Yes, I assume so as well :)
I am planning to do this with [~gcca].
[~amol-] is this still open? or are you working on this?
I just took it the other day to get remember tackling it,  but I haven't yet done any work as I'm finishing another one. I hope to be able to include it in 7.0.0 btw
[~amol-] Shall I take it up? I think it is fairly straight forward.
[~niranda] Let me give it a try, if I don't do it by this week I'll gladly give it to you ;)
